conclusion: Semi-cylindrical transparent brick with refractive index n and radius r; laser beam hits point A and moves down at constant speed V along AC; find when light emerges from arc surface ABC; propagation time inside brick ignored
Beam enters perpendicular to AC, refracts at curved surface
Set up coordinate system with origin at O, y-axis along OA, x-axis perpendicular to AC; A at (0,r) and C at (0,-r)
Ray entering at position (0,y) travels horizontally, hits semicircle at (x1,y) where x1 = sqrt(r^2-y^2)
Apply Snell's Law at exit point (x1,y); normal to surface along radial direction from O to (x1,y); angle of incidence theta_i = arccos(x1/r) = arccos(sqrt(r^2-y^2)/r); n sin(theta_i) = sin(theta_r)
Ray emerges from curved surface at same time it enters flat surface; laser beam reaches position y at time t = (r-y)/V
Critical condition when refracted ray tangent to curved surface; theta_r = 90Â°; n sin(theta_i) = 1; sin(theta_i) = 1/n; theta_i = arcsin(1/n)
Theta_i = arccos(sqrt(r^2-y^2)/r); arccos(sqrt(r^2-y^2)/r) = arcsin(1/n); arcsin(sqrt(1-(sqrt(r^2-y^2)/r)^2)) = arcsin(1/n); arcsin(|y|/r) = arcsin(1/n); |y|/r = 1/n; |y| = r/n
Since moving from A toward C, y is positive above O and negative below O; y = -r/n (below O)
Time when beam reaches position y = -r/n is t = (r-(-r/n))/V = r(1+1/n)/V = r(n+1)/nV
Moment when light emerges from arc surface ABC is t = r(n+1)/nV
